docs.lead_paragraph: Voices around the country no longer talk of economic booms or Internet riches, of golden-hued nest eggs or second homes on beach property. In January 2000, the Dow Jones industrial average peaked at 11,723; it now has spiraled down toward 8,000. The Dow plummeted 1,369 points, or 14 percent, last week alone in its worst weekly decline since the Great Depression, with more than $1 trillion in stock market wealth wiped out.

headline.main: Investors Try To Adjust To a New Set Of Realities

docs.abstract: Individual investors are adjusting to new set of realities in wake of terrorist attacks; seem hesitant, uncertain and noncommittal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH 15 million square feet of office space in lower Manhattan lost on Sept. 11 and another 10 million square feet at least temporarily unusable, companies displaced by the attack on the World Trade Center are turning to suburbs like Westchester, where vacancy rates have been rising. Westchester has about five million square feet of office space available, county officials said.

headline.main: Hoping to Fill the Need for Office Space

docs.abstract: Westchester County, NY, and White Plains, in particular, could help fill need for 15 million square feet of office space lost and another 10 million square feet temporarily unusable in Manhattan because of attack on World Trade Center; county has about 5 million square feet of office space available; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDER GRASHOW was in the midst of a six-week trip in southern Africa last spring when his journey turned into a nightmare -- a series of them, to be precise. He had done extensive Internet research on health-related precautions, including how to avoid mosquito-borne diseases, but nothing he'd read had prepared him for the bizarre dreams that plagued him almost as soon as he closed his eyes.

headline.main: Health Resources for Travelers on the Web

docs.abstract: Bob Tedeschi article describes some health-related Web sites for travelers; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FIRST came the physical devastation of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, then the emotional shock waves, and now the families of the victims are likely to face financial trauma as well. Recalling what she called ''the dragon'' that followed the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995, Trish Goodman, a certified financial planner who is president of the Financial Planning Association of Central Oklahoma, said, ''The most unexpected reality is that when the dust settles, the financial hardship sets in.''

headline.main: Personal Business; When Grief Meets the Reality of Financial Planning

docs.abstract: Experts offer advice on dealing with personal financial trauma caused terrorist attacks of Sept 11; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are countless stories to tell: the man who walked into the Greenwich chapter of the American Red Cross and handed a worker a check for $10,000. ''I don't know what else to do,'' he said. The students in a South Windsor English honors class, who raised $5,000 and a truckload of food and supplies in 48 hours. The residents who filled up shopping carts at Wal-Mart and donated all their purchases to the Salvation Army. In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, ''Everybody is just hungry to reach out and help,'' said Sandra Ahola, the principal of the Pomfret Community School in northeastern Connecticut. ''They want to show their compassion, their love, their caring.''

headline.main: Coming With Cash, Food and Themselves

docs.lead_paragraph: On the cast that covers Cathy Nash's right leg, there is a drawing of the twin towers above a wide smile. Next to the towers is a drawing of the American flag and below that, a note written by a proud daughter to her courageous mother. ''Dear Mom,'' the note says, ''Good job helping out -- Love, Deirdre.''

headline.main: Some of Those Who Helped Now Need Help

docs.abstract: Article on The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund; Cathy Nash and her daughter Jennifer Petrillo, both nurses who helped rescue people at World Trade Center, are now in need of aid because of wages lost; Nash suffered broken leg; photo (S)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: THINGS did not look good. The stock market was down to three-year lows. Many companies were reporting weak earnings and eliminating executive bonuses and hundreds of thousands of jobs. The unemployment rate had climbed to 4.9 percent and consumer spending had slowed. That's what the economy looked like before the world stood still on Sept. 11, not that many people can now remember that far back. I can. A friend of mine who had worked for her company for about 10 years was laid off when her company decided to outsource her job. Another friend, thrilled about a job that paid almost two-thirds more than her previous one, lost it when her company let several people go. As if that wasn't bad enough, after she hurriedly scheduled a doctor's appointment before her health insurance ran out, she was told that she had skin cancer. (She is receiving treatment, and has even found another job, but she had to settle for less than her previous salary.)

headline.main: Time For the Boomers To Dig In

docs.lead_paragraph: CHARLES ALBERS and Nikolaos Monoyios spent last week setting up the computer systems needed to manage their portfolios from makeshift quarters in central New Jersey, their temporary home after their offices at the headquarters of OppenheimerFunds were destroyed in the attack on the World Trade Center. ''Our space was vaporized,'' said Mr. Albers, who was on his way to work at the time of the attack. ''I saw it fall before my eyes.''

headline.main: Investing; New Offices, Mixed Emotions at Fund Companies

docs.abstract: Mutual fund companies displaced by Sept 11 attacks try to regroup and continue in business despite, in many cases, absence of employees who were victims of tragedy; photo (M)

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and ELIZABETH HARRIS

docs.lead_paragraph: Dow Posts Its Worst Loss Since the Great Depression America's stock markets ended one of the worst weeks in their history, as fears of a deepening recession led many investors to move their money out of stocks into less risky assets. For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average posted a 14.3 percent loss, its largest since the Depression. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 140.40 points yesterday, to 8,235.81. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which includes the largest publicly traded companies, ended yesterday just above its low of Aug. 31, 1998, the last time fears of a worldwide recession overwhelmed Wall Street. The S.& P. fell 18.74 points, to 965.80, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 47.74 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,423.19. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: When President Bush first sat down with his full cabinet after last week's terrorist attacks, he told them that nothing about their roles or charges as federal officials would ever be the same. ''I expect you to work hard on our agenda,'' Mr. Bush said, an almost obligatory nod to the various initiatives, like education reform and prescription drug coverage, that had consumed their attention before Sept. 11.

headline.main: For President, a Mission and a Role in History
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: WHITE HOUSE MEMO

docs.abstract: Pres Bush tells his aides and Cabinet that war on terrorism that he plans to wage has now become purpose of his administration, even while giving almost obligatory nod to various initiatives, like education reform and prescription drug coverage, that had consumed their attention before Sept 11; Bush's friends and advisers say that terrorism issue has wholly transformed Bush's sense of himself and his presidency; they say he believes that he has come face to face with his life's mission, task by which he will be defined and judged; photo of Bush with aides Mike Gerson, Condeleezza Rice and and Karen P Hughes (L)
